metadata.title: Influence of preparation methods on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Mn-Ce catalysts for lean methane combustion

Table 4 Sample O 1s position(eV) Oα/(Oα+ Oβ) Mn 2p3/2 position(eV) Mn4+/Mn3+ Ce3+/Ce4+ Oα Oβ Oω Mn4+ Mn3+ MnCe-RP 529.6 531.6 533.0 0.85 642.6 641.6 3.56 0.39 MnCe-CP 529.8 531.5 533.0 0.80 642.4 641.6 1.02 0.29 a.Theoretical H2 uptake for reduction of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP, as calculated by assuming that MnOx is as KxMn8O16 (x = 1) or Mn5O8 (CeO2 was ignored) Influence of preparation methods on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Mn-Ce catalysts for lean methane combustion Liu Zhong Qingyan Fang ⁎ Xin Li Quan Li Cheng Zhang Gang Chen ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion, School of Energy and Power Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion School of Energy and Power Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Various catalysts were synthesized by the redox-precipitation (RP) and co-precipitation (CP) methods, and their catalytic performances for the complete catalytic oxidation of lean methane combustion were investigated. The synthetic catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, Raman, XPS, TG, UV–vis and H2-TPR. MnCe-RP showed 50% methane conversion to CO2 at ˜446 °C, which was 23 °C lower the temperature required for MnCe-CP. The active components (KxMn8O16) in the bulk and on the surface of MnCe-RP were confirmed. The redox-precipitation method synthesized open nanorod and nanosphere catalysts containing KxMn8O16 and Mn5O8, whereas the co-precipitation method synthesized agglomerate catalysts containing only Mn5O8. The higher surface-concentrations of Mn4+, Ce3+ and Oα on MnCe-RP are beneficial for its higher catalytic performance. Furthermore, the optical bandgap value of MnCe-RP is lower than that of MnCe-CP, and the K ion in KxMn8O16 may weaken the Mn-O bond, improving the catalyst reducibility, especially for the reduction process of Mn3O4→MnO. Keywords The redox-precipitation method KxMn8O16 Mn-Ce catalyst Lean methane Catalytic combustion 1 Introduction Natural gas, which is mostly methane, will likely be increasingly adopted as a fuel for the on-road transportation sector in the upcoming years [1], because it is a cleaner fuel that produces only CO2 when combusted. However, its warming potential is over 20 times higher than that of CO2, and, thus, methane is classified as one of the most dangerous atmospheric pollutants. Methane contributes approximately 18.6% of the total warming gas shares, and the increased rate of methane concentration (252%) in the atmosphere is more than that of CO2 (134%). However, CH4 molecules have high chemical stability, making catalytic combustion a promising potential technology because of low NOx emission and a wide accommodation limit for methane concentration. It is critical for catalysts to have low-temperature ignition performance and high-temperature thermal stability. There are two main kinds of catalysts: noble metals and their oxides and non-noble catalysts. Even though noble metal-based catalysts exhibit higher performance in comparison to the metal oxide catalysts in low-temperature windows, their price and thermal stability and the influence of water and sulfur at higher temperatures have turned researchers’ attention toward less expensive and more thermally stable alternatives, such as TMOs (transition-metal oxides) [2]. The transition-metal oxide catalysts may be more suitable alternatives to the noble-metal-containing catalysts. There are many oxide catalysts, such as Co3O4 [3], MnO2 [2], CuO [4], whereas binary oxide systems, such as MnOx-CeO2 [1], NiO-MnOx [5], NiO-CeO2 [6], CoO-CeO2 [7], and CuO-CeO2 [8], attract wide scientific interest. Mn-Ce catalysts have been investigated extensively in terms of NH3-SCR [9], CWAO [10], Ammoxidation [11], etc, due to their excellent catalytic efﬁciency in low-temperatures. However, some studies have shown that the redox properties of Mn-Ce catalysts are strongly dependent on preparation methods [12]. Arena et al. [10,13,14] and Wu et al. [15,16] reported a new method for synthesizing Mn-Ce mixed oxides by redox-precipitation reactions using KMnO4, Mn(NO3)2 and (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 or Ce(NO3)2 as precursors. Additionally, the catalytic performance is better than with other methods. However, the catalyst made by the redox-precipitation method was only used in CWAO [14] and complete catalytic oxidation of VOCs at low temperatures [16]. No investigations of this synthesis method for methane catalytic combustion were found, likely because MnO2 decomposes to Mn5O8 and Mn2O3 at −400–550 °C, which is the main temperature range for methane oxidation by O2 with catalysts. Furthermore, the performance of MnO2 is better than that of Mn5O8 and Mn2O3 [2]. Recently, our group developed the redox-precipitation method for the preparation of Mn-Ce catalysts for the complete catalytic oxidation of lean methane combustion [17]. The Mn-Ce catalyst catalyzed the conversion of half of the methane (1 vol %) into CO2 and H2O at 446 °C. It was found that KxMn8O16 was the main active phase providing the lattice oxygen species and that CeO2 enhanced oxygen mobility. The synergistic effects between KxMn8O16 and CeO2 promoted the redox behavior of the catalyst and significantly improved its activity toward the complete catalytic oxidation of methane. In this paper, the performance comparison between the catalysts synthesized by the redox-precipitation and co-precipitation methods was further investigated. The two catalysts were tested for the complete catalytic oxidation of 1 vol% methane. The effects of specific surface area, the surface concentration of Mn4+, Ce3+ and Oα ions over Mn-Ce catalysts and the value of optical band-gap on their catalytic performances toward methane catalytic combustion were investigated. Other effects such as morphology and thermal ability were discussed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis by different methods 2.1.1 Redox-precipitation method (RP) The Mn-Ce catalyst was prepared by the redox-precipitation method, as previous published [13,18]. In a brief, titration at constant pH (4.5 ± 0.3, by addition of 0.4 M KOH(Aladdin Industrial Corporation Co., Ltd. (China))) of Mn(NO3)2(Aladdin Industrial Corporation Co., Ltd. (China))was performed with a solution of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 (Aladdin Industrial Corporation Co., Ltd. (China)) and KMnO4 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd). After titration, the precipitate was washed with Ultra-pure water (18.2 MΩ) and ethanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) three times. The solid was dried at 100℃ (12 h) and further calcined (6 h) in air at 500℃. The catalysts were ground, tableted, crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh to reduce the influence of internal diffusion and external diffusion. According to previous work, the Mn molar content in the Mn-Ce catalysts was 90%, and the catalyst was named MnCe-RP. 2.1.2 Co-precipitation method (CP) The Mn-Ce catalyst was prepared by a co-precipitation method as previous published [1]. In a brief, the concentrated solutions of the Mn2+ and Ce4+ nitrates precursors were used. The precipitating agent, 2 M KOH solution, was added dropwise to the solutions of precursors at a temperature of approximately 60℃ until pH was equal to 10.0. After titration, the precipitate was washed with Ultra-pure water and ethanol three times. The solid was dried at 100℃ (12 h) and further calcined (6 h) in air at 500℃. The catalysts were ground, tableted, crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh and named MnCe-CP. 2.2 Characterization 2.2.1 Specific surface area (BET) The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) equations based on data obtained by the N2 adsorption-desorption experiment. The isotherms were collected on a physical adsorption station (ASAP 2020, Micromeritics). Samples were pretreated in a vacuum at 300℃ for 4 h, and then N2 was adsorbed and desorbed at −196℃ (the boiling temperature of N2) at 6.7 Pa. 2.2.2 Laser Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were collected on a HORIBA Scientiﬁc LabRAM HR 800 Raman spectrometer system equipped with a 532-nm laser. A laser energy ﬁlter value of two was applied to provide 0.5 mw power laser. The spectra were taken between 100 and 800 cm−1 in a backscattering conﬁguration at room temperature. 2.2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X'pert3 Powder X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical, Inc.) operated at 60 kV and 60 mA, using Ni-filtered Cu-Ka radiation by step scanning with a scan angle of 5°–85°. 2.2.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was conducted with XPS equipment (AXIS-ULTRADLD-600 W Kratos). The X-rays were produced by an Al source and the Ka line was selected. The obtained spectra were corrected by shifting the C-C peak in the C1 s spectra to 285.0 eV A Shirley background was used for peak fitting. Peaks were separated by XPSpeak 4.1 and fitted by Gaussian shape. 2.2.5 Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using a Diamond TG/DTG (PerkinElmer Instruments) with simultaneous recording of TG and DTG curves in relation to temperature and time (heating rate: 10 °C/min, temperature range: 100–1000 °C, sample mass: 1 mg). 2.2.6 Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV–vis) Transmittance spectra were recorded using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Solid Spec-3700) in the wavelength region of 200–2500 nm at room temperature. 2.2.7 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) A Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope was used for image observation of the samples at the acceleration voltage of 10 kV. Samples for SEM analyses were placed on the sample holders supported by carbon paint followed by 80 s of sputter coating with gold. 2.2.8 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) The elements type of sample surface was collected on a EAGLE III equipment with rhodium tube and a maximum power of 40 W. 2.2.9 H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR-MS) H2-TPR-MS was conducted on a chemical adsorption station (AutoChem II 2920, Micromeritics) equipped with a QMS detector (Hiden Inc.). 50 mg samples were pretreated in a 50 ml/min Ar at 400℃ for 30 min and cooled to 50℃ until the signal stabilized. The temperature was elevated at a rate of 10℃/min from 50℃ up to 700℃, while keeping the 10% H2 (N2 balanced) flow at a rate of 50 mL/min. 2.3 Catalytic performance measurements Catalytic performances were measured over a custom-built fixed reactor (id = 6 mm), as shown in Fig. 1 , with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 30,000 ml/(h*g) at 360–600℃ and atmospheric pressure. A thermocouple was attached to the external surface of the reactor at the catalyst bed to record reaction temperature. The reaction gases consisted of 1 vol% CH4, 10 vol% O2, and the balance N2 to simulate the real gas. The total mass flow rate was maintained at 100 ml/min. Catalysts were pretreated in 100 ml/min air at 400℃ for 30 min, and the remnant gaseous O2 was flushed with N2 for 30 min. After the temperature of the reaction tube cooled from 400℃ to 360℃, the experiment started, and the concentrations of CH4, CO, and CO2 at reactor inlet and outlet were measured by GC9700II with two detectors of FID and TCD (no CO and H2 were detected during the experiments of methane combustion, and methane was totally oxidized to CO2). To ensure the accuracy of the measurement, the reaction gas was analyzed with the GC after 30 min. of the temperature of the tube furnace becoming the elevated value. Conversions of CH4 was calculated as follows: X C H 4 = C i n - C o u t C i n × 100 % Where Cin is the CH4 concentration in the feed gas (vol %); Cout is the CH4 concentration in the produced gas (vol %); 1. Pressure reducing value; 2. Mass flow meter; 3. Mix tanker; 4. Reaction tube; 5. Tube furnace; 6. Temperature controller; 7. Gas chromatography; 8. Microcomputer workstation 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performances of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP for lean methane combustion are shown in Fig. 2 . The results indicated the performance of catalysts were significantly affected by the catalyst preparation method. The temperature to reach a methane conversion of 50% (T50) is regarded as a criterion of the catalytic performance for methane combustion, especially for MnOx [1]. The MnCe-RP catalyst showed 50% of methane conversion at ˜446 °C while the MnCe-CP catalyst exhibited the same conversion efficiency at ˜469 °C, 23 °C higher than the MnCe-RP catalyst, indicating that MnCe-RP had higher catalytic activity than MnCe-CP. Moreover, compared with some other optimized Mn-Ce catalysts for the lean methane combustion [1,19–24], as listed in Table 1 , the MnCe-RP catalyst also exhibits the highest ratio of Mn-to-Ce and relatively higher performance. This suggests that the catalyst made by the redox-precipitation method is competitive, due to the lowest Ce content [25] and relatively higher performance. 3.2 BET, XRD & Raman and SEM analysis The BET surface area and pore volume of MnCe-RP are 111 m2 g−1 and 62.38 cm3 g−1, respectively, appreciably larger than those of MnCe-CP (47 m2 g−1 and 31.74 cm3 g−1). However, the pore size of MnCe-RP is only 21.8 nm and smaller than that of MnCe-CP (23.0 nm). These results indicate that the preparation method greatly affects the physical properties of these catalysts. The higher BET surface area and pore volume, which may provide more active sites and promote the adsorption and diffusion of reactant molecules, could improve the performance of the catalyst. XRD patterns and Raman spectra of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP are shown in Fig. 3 . In the XRD patterns of MnCe-CP, the peaks of CeO2 (JCPDS 34-0394) and Mn5O8 (JCPDS 39-1218) can be clearly observed, which is similar with the result of the report by Wu et al. [15]. However, there is a marked difference, and the details will be provided in H2-TPR analysis. Compared with the diffraction patterns of MnCe-CP, there are indications of KxMn8O16 (JCPDS 42-1348) in that of MnCe-RP. It could be clearly observed that there are two new peaks between 10° and 20° in the XRD patterns, which are characteristic peaks of KxMn8O16 [27]. From our experiment, the performance of MnCe-RP was remarkably better than that of MnCe-CP, indicated by the decreasing order of methane conversions by KxMn8O16 ≈ MnO2 > Mn5O8 [2,28]. In all collected Raman spectra in Fig. 3B, the characteristic bands assigned to Ag-vibrations of Mn5O8 (band at approximately 171 cm−1, 264 cm−1, 477 cm−1, 533 cm−1 and 570 cm−1 [29]) and KxMn8O16 (band at approximately 182 cm−1, 377 cm−1, 567 cm−1 and 652 cm−1 [30]) can be identified. The results from the Raman spectra are consistent with that of XRD. Further insights into the influence of the preparation method on the structural features of the catalysts came from SEM images of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP before reaction. The texture and morphology of MnCe-RP are markedly different from that of MnCe-CP. The MnCe-RP consisted of a series of nanorods and nanosphere. However, there was serious sintering and agglomeration of MnCe-CP. As previously suggested, the performance of the catalyst is better when the average particle size is smaller [15]. To evaluate the effect of preparation method on the dispersion of Mn on the catalyst surface and in the catalyst bulk, the surface and bulk Mn/Ce atomic ratios were calculated based on the EDS and XRF data, respectively. These results are given in Table 2 . For both MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP, the Mn/Ce surface values were similar to the bulk atomic composition, which indicates that MnOx and CeO2 are homogeneously dispersed in the catalysts. However, the Mn/Ce values of MnCe-RP (˜11.6) is higher than theory value (9.0), while that of MnCe-CP (˜8.4) is lower than theory value. The incorporation of Ce cations dopes into the KxMn8O16 lattice in MnCe-RP sample, due to that the MnO6 octahedra has a 2 × 2 tunnel structure with the size of 0.46 × 0.46 nm [31], and the tunnel radius of MnO6 octahedra is bigger than ionic radii of Ce3+(0.103 nm), Ce4+(0.099 nm). In MnCe-CP sample, however, the all ionic radii of Mn2+(0.083 nm), Mn3+(0.066 nm) and Mn4+(0.056 nm)are smaller than that of Ce3+ and Ce4+ [32], due to partial Mn cations doping into Ce lattice, forming Mn-Ce solid solution (Fig. 4 ). 3.3 XPS analysis To measure the composition and oxidation states of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP, XPS spectra were taken on the two samples. Fig. 5 (A) shows the XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2 in MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP. Based on previous literature [1,13] and the current XRD & Raman results, the catalyst made by the redox-precipitation and co-precipitation methods consist of more Mn4+ and Mn3+, and less Mn2+. In addition, the peaks approximately 642.4–642.9 eV and 641.6–641.9 eV are attributed to the presence of Mn4+ and Mn3+ species, respectively (the Mn2+ peak was ignored). Compared with the MnCe-CP peak, the XPS peak at 642.1 eV of MnCe-RP is sharper, which indicates that there is a main stabilization manganese oxide [31], consisting of more Mn4+ and likely due to KxMn8O16. More Mn4+ suggests Mn 2p3/2 possesses higher bond energy, which indicates that fewer electrons are transferred from Ce to Mn during the precipitation process [32]. According to the comparison between the peak areas of Mn4+ and Mn3+ listed in Table 3 , the ratio of Mn4+-to-Mn3+ over the surface of MnCe-RP (3.56) is remarkably higher than that of MnCe-CP (1.02). There is a higher Mn4+ content in the MnCe-RP catalyst, which is beneficial to the performance of methane catalytic combustion [20]. The Ce 3d spectra are frequently used to identify oxygen mobility and redox capability. Based on previous literature [33], the peaks named as u```, u``, u, v```, v`` and v arise from the Ce4+ contribution, while Ce3+ is characterized by two other peaks in Fig. 5(B). There is a coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in the MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP indicating the formation of oxygen vacancies, which can boost the oxygen transfer rate during methane oxidation [34]. Comparing the peaks area of Ce4+ and Ce3+ listed in Table 3, over the surface of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP, Ce4+ is the main valence of both MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP. However, the ratio of Ce3+-to-Ce4+ over the surface of MnCe-RP (0.39) is higher than that of MnCe-CP (0.29). Thus, there is a higher Ce3+ content in MnCe-RP catalyst, which is beneficial to the performance of methane catalytic combustion [35]. The O 1 s spectra are frequently used to identify the types of oxygen species over the surface of catalysts. The chemical environment of oxygen in metal oxide catalysts plays a critical role in their catalytic properties. The XPS spectra of O 1 s over the surface of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP are shown in Fig. 5(C). For both catalysts, O 1 s spectra were divided into three types peak: the peak at BE of 529.6–529.9 eV was ascribed to the lattice oxygen (denoted as Oα), the peak at BE of 531.4–531.6 eV was ascribed to chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ), and the peak at a higher BE (above 533.0 eV) corresponded to adsorbed water (denoted as Oω) [15]. As listed in Table 3, over the surface of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP, the Oα is the main component of both, indicated by the higher ratio of Mn-to-Ce [15]. However, compared with MnCe-CP, the fraction of Oα over the surface of MnCe-RP (0.85) is higher than that of MnCe-CP (0.80). The Oω peak area was ignored, because the adsorbed water was independent of the reaction. The oxidation of methane over manganese oxide catalysts usually proceeds according to the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [36,37]. The lattice oxygen of manganese oxide was considered to be the primary active species for activating the C–H bonds above 400 °C. Thus, there are three parameters determining the performance of methane catalytic combustion: (1) higher oxidation state of manganese species, (2) lower oxidation state of Cerium species and (3) higher content of lattice oxygen over the surface of catalysts. 3.4 UV–vis-DRS analysis UV-vis-DRS was used to determine the absorption of the samples at different wavelengths. The UV–vis spectra of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP are shown in Fig. 6 (A), and the value of optical bandgap was calculated by the Kubelka-Munk function in Fig. 6 (B). There is remarkable difference in absorbance in the range of 700–2500 nm shown in Fig. 6 (A), which indicated that the absorbance capacity of MnCe-RP in the near infrared area is stronger than that of MnCe-CP. The value of the optical band-gap can be calculated by the UV–vis spectra, which corresponds to electron excitation from the valence band to the conduction band. The absorption coefﬁcient (α) and the incident photon energy (hν) are related by the equation [38]: ( α h ν ) 1 / n = A ( h ν - E g ) where A is a constant, Eg is the band-gap of the material and the exponent n depends on the type of transition, n = 1/2, 2, 3/2 and 3 corresponding to allowed direct, allowed indirect, forbidden direct and forbidden indirect, respectively. The number n = 1/2 was used in our calculation, because MnCeOx is a direct bandgap semiconductor [38]. The energy band-gap of MnCe-RP (1.787 eV) was lower than that of MnCe-CP (1.824 eV). The bandgap narrowed, which is beneficial for improving the oxygen transfer rate and improving catalyst performance. Thus, lower energy band-gaps correspond to higher redox properties for as-prepared Mn-Ce catalysts. 3.5 TG-DTG analysis Comparison of TG-DTG curves (Fig. 7 ) shows that the course of thermal decomposition of MnCe-RP is similar to that of MnCe-CP at 100℃–900℃. The several major weight losses of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP can be principally divided into two groups as dehydration and oxygen evolution [39,40]. The dehydration of MnCe-RP includes the evaporation of the physisorbed water (approximately 100–200 °C) and the oxygen release from catalyst surface (approximately 200–400 °C) [41], shown in Fig. S1, and the corresponding weight losses were approximately 4.07% and 2.64%, respectively. However, the corresponding weight loss of MnCe-CP physisorbed water (approximately 100–300 ℃) and chemisorbed water (approximately 300–500 ℃) [42], shown in Fig. S2, were approximately 0.72% and 0.71% (the loss of oxygen was ignored), respectively. Due to the different crystal phases, there was one more oxygen evolution of MnCe-RP at approximately 400–600℃, and the weight loss was approximately 5.74%, which is due to KxMn8O16 to Mn2O3 [43]. The rest of the weight loss during MnCe-RP oxygen evolution was due to Mn5O8 to Mn2O3 (approximately 600–870 ℃) and Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 (approximately 870–920 °C) conversion [44], 3.66% and 4.03%, respectively. However, the oxygen evolution of MnCe-CP just included oxygen evolution processes of Mn5O8 to Mn2O3 (approximately 500–800 °C) and Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 (approximately 800–970 °C), of which the corresponding weight losses were approximately 1.99% and 3.31%, respectively (Table 4 ). 3.6 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR was performed to characterize the redox properties of materials. The corresponding H2-TPR profiles of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP in the temperature range 50-700℃ are shown in Fig. 8 . Both catalysts exhibited excellent redox properties in the temperature range 150–500℃. However, there was a marked difference between MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP. The MnCe-RP catalyst exhibited one main reduction peak with two shoulder peaks at low temperature, and the MnCe-CP catalyst showed two main reduction peaks at low temperature and high temperature and just one shoulder peak at low temperature. The reduction signal of MnCe-RP was divided into three peaks at approximately 224℃, 275℃ and 301℃, named as α, β and λ [45], respectively. Further, for the MnCe-CP catalyst, the reduction signal was divided into three peaks at approximately 187℃, 276℃ and 389℃, and named α, β and λ [46], respectively. The α peak was attributed to the active oxygen species on the catalyst surface, and the peaks of β and λ were attributed to the reduction of KxMn8O16 or Mn5O8→Mn3O4 and Mn3O4→MnO [45,46], assuming that MnO was the ﬁnal reduction state from various Mn species in the initial MnOx [47]. The area of the different peaks was obtained by integration. In the MnCe-RP catalyst, the area ratio of β to λ was approximately 1.10, which was between the H2-consumption of KxMn8O16 at 1.875 and that of Mn5O8 at 0.8. Furthermore, in the MnCe-CP catalyst, the area ratio of β to λ was approximately 0.75, lower than 0.8 and likely due to the partial reduction peaks of CeO2 at 300-550℃ [48]. The λ peak position of MnCe-RP is remarkably lower than that of MnCe-CP, which may be attributable to the K ion in KxMn8O16, which weakens the Mn-O bond [15] and is beneficial for the reduction process of Mn3O4→MnO. The β peak H2-consumption of MnCe-RP (4.5 mmol/g) was higher than that of MnCe-CP (3.6 mmol/g), but the λ peak H2-consumption of MnCe-RP (4.1 mmol/g) was lower than that of MnCe-CP (4.8 mmol/g), indicating that the Mn4+ content in MnCe-RP was higher than that of MnCe-CP. These results were consistent with the results of XRD, Raman, and XPS (Fig. 9 ). 3.7 Thermal stability The catalytic stability of MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP catalysts were investigated for isothermal combustion of methane at 600℃ for >21 h. In 21 h, both MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP catalysts showed a remarkably stable performance. MnCe-RP still achieved 99.94% of the initial conversion of CH4 after 21 h, and MnCe-RP still achieves 92.80% of the initial conversion of CH4. However, the change rate of the MnCe-RP performance (0.06%) was remarkably lower than that of the MnCe-CP performance (8.2%), which indicates the MnCe-RP catalyst holds relatively better thermal stability and longer service life. 4 Conclusions The results obtained for MnCe-RP and MnCe-CP synthesized by the redox-precipitation and co-precipitation methods, respectively, conﬁrmed their performance for total combustion of CH4 at concentrations as low as 1 vol %. The results of this investigation lead us to draw the following conclusions: • MnCe-RP showed 50% methane conversion to CO2 at ˜446 °C, 23 °C lower than the catalyst prepared via the co-precipitation method (˜469 °C). • The catalyst(MnCe-RP) made by the redox-precipitation method had a high BET surface area and pore volume, which may provide more active sites and promote the adsorption and diffusion of reactant molecules. • The ratios of Mn4+-to-Mn3+ and Ce3+-to-Ce4+ and the fraction of Oα over catalyst surface of MnCe-RP (3.56, 0.39 and 0.85) were higher than those of MnCe-CP (1.02, 0.29 and 0.80). • The optical bandgap value of MnCe-RP (1.787) was lower than that of MnCe-CP. • The K ion in KxMn8O16 may weaken Mn-O bonds, benefiting the reducibility of the catalyst, especially for the reduction process of Mn3O4→MnO. This redox-precipitation method is environmentally friendly, requires lower temperatures and is suitable for facile large-scale synthesis at atmospheric pressure of highly active catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of methane. coredata.dc:description: Various catalysts were synthesized by the redox-precipitation (RP) and co-precipitation (CP) methods, and their catalytic performances for the complete catalytic oxidation of lean methane combustion were investigated. The synthetic catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, Raman, XPS, TG, UV–vis and H2-TPR. MnCe-RP showed 50% methane conversion to CO2 at ˜446 °C, which was 23 °C lower the temperature required for MnCe-CP. The active components (KxMn8O16) in the bulk and on the surface of MnCe-RP were confirmed. The redox-precipitation method synthesized open nanorod and nanosphere catalysts containing KxMn8O16 and Mn5O8, whereas the co-precipitation method synthesized agglomerate catalysts containing only Mn5O8. The higher surface-concentrations of Mn4+, Ce3+ and Oα on MnCe-RP are beneficial for its higher catalytic performance. Furthermore, the optical bandgap value of MnCe-RP is lower than that of MnCe-CP, and the K ion in KxMn8O16 may weaken the Mn-O bond, improving the catalyst reducibility, especially for the reduction process of Mn3O4→MnO.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of preparation methods on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Mn-Ce catalysts for lean methane combustion
